General policy directive on the aims and format
of this discussion series
It is best to begin by saying what this series is not.
This series is not an European radio reporter series
with a newspaper expert providing a roundup of the news
of Europe. It is not a radio commentator series a la H.
V. Kaltenborn or Edward E, Murrow. It is not a series of
Round Table discussions on assigned topics to which several
participants devote their efforts in trying to present
solutions.
The aim of the series is to bring to the American public, through
friendly interviews, in he bluntest and most direct fashion possible, the
statements and views of range of people who, collectively, will reflect
in a general way the major political and social lines of thought being fol¬
lowed by important opinion groups in Europe, It is recognized that this is
a difficult undertaking, dnce no one can be completely sure what the true
public opinion condition is in Europe on all issues and there is no scienti¬
fic method of assessing this. In practice we must present the series with
good taste and with the necessary qualifications made clear, as for example,
that the guest on this program is a co; 1 miner who works in the Saar and
vhose three sons died in the German army at Stalingrad, that he was so many
years a Nasi, and that this particular individual is now going to tell us
what he thinks about certain things that matter to him. It will be desir¬
able at the end of mch interviews to re-identify this person as an individ¬
ual and to remind the listener that he is in no way presented as reflecting
the official opinion of any country or government. We hope, then, in this
series to present interesting and informative interviews with a wide range
of European people. We would hope that interviews could be obtained with
refugees, ex-Nazis, neo-Nazis, French Communists, French ex-Conmiunists,
French radicals, German-Bavarian Catholics, and so on.
In some instances, interviews may possibly be organized around a
central difficulty, such as the success of the Marshall Plan in Italy, or
the problem of the unification of Germany. Because of the time lag between
the creation of these interview programs in Europe and their presentation
on American radio stations, it will be necessary to center on those non-
topical subjects which have a continuing importance and are likely to be
pressing and interesting problera3three, six, twelve months or more after
the interview. It will be necessary to avoid the current events approach.
As a further example of what might be done within this series, the
suggestion is made that interviews be obtained with the "left-over people,"
that is, the refugees in Germany, Austria, and elsewhere, who are stateless.
The hope is that all of these programs would be finished by June 15
or July 1 at the latest.
